Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: I walked beside my younger brother, our backpacks bouncing as we made our way down the familiar street. Mom always said to look out for him, especially after what happened last year. I kept glancing at him, making sure he stayed close, my mind replaying her words: “You’re his big sister. He needs you.” But today was Wednesday, and the church youth group was meeting in less than an hour. Pastor Lee had reminded us all on Sunday—attendance was important, not just for worship, but to show commitment to our faith and community. I could already picture the empty seat if I didn’t show up, the questions, the disappointment. But my brother’s face was pale, and he kept coughing, slower than usual. I knew he wasn’t feeling well, and I didn’t want to leave him alone at home. My phone buzzed with a reminder from the church group chat. I felt torn, my heart pounding, caught between the duty to care for my brother and the expectation to be present at church. I slowed my steps, wrestling with what I should do next.
